title: Sarah Paine EP 1: The War For India (Lecture & Interview)

metadata.summary: This episode features Professor Sarah Paine discussing the complex interplay of great power politics in South Asia, focusing on the rivalry between China and India. The lecture covers pivotal decisions made by leaders such as Khrushchev, Mao, Nehru, Bhutto, and Lyndon Johnson, and their lasting impact on the region. Topics include the Sino-Indian War, US involvement in the area, the role of the Soviet Union, and the impact of these events on the Cold War. The episode also explores the strategic importance of Pakistan, the rise of nuclear weapons in the region, and the long-term consequences of these geopolitical maneuvers.

topClaims.text: The 1955 Baghdad Pact between the United States and Pakistan poisoned U.S. relations with India for the duration of the Cold War.
The 1962 Sino-Indian War transformed India's leadership from idealistic and cooperative to militarized and hostile towards China.
After the 1969 war, Russia and China became each other's primary enemy, giving the United States a strategic advantage in the Cold War.
The United States abetted a genocide in Bangladesh in order to facilitate diplomatic relations with China in 1971.
Russians have been uniquely cruel to each other throughout history, particularly after the communist revolution.

topQuotes.text: Intervening in someone else's problems is a cottage industry for the United States.
Nehru... is horrified. A military pact between Pakistan and the United States changes the whole balance of power in this part of the world.
The United States prioritized its diplomatic relations with China over addressing the humanitarian crisis in Pakistan during the 1971 presidential elections.
The United States abetted a genocide in Bangladesh in order to facilitate diplomatic relations with China in 1971.
It's unbelievable how cruel the Russians have been to each other and others.

topTopics.name: sino indian war
topTopics.description: The complex relationship between India and China.

topTopics.name: us foreign policy
topTopics.description: The role of the United States in South Asia.

topTopics.name: cold war politics
topTopics.description: The impact of the Cold War on the region.

topTopics.name: nuclear proliferation
topTopics.description: The rise of nuclear weapons in the region.

snippet.title: Sarah Paine EP 1: The War For India (Lecture & Interview)

localized.title: Sarah Paine EP 1: The War For India (Lecture & Interview)
localized.description:
How the rivalry between China and India reshaped Asia forever

I’m thrilled to launch a trilogy of episodes: a lecture series by Professor Sarah Paine of the Naval War College, each followed by a deep Q&A. 

In this first episode, Prof Paine talks about key decisions by Khrushchev, Mao, Nehru, Bhutto, & Lyndon Johnson that shaped the whole dynamic of South Asia today. This is followed by a Q&A with me. 

Come for the spy bases, shoestring nukes, and insight about how great power politics impacts every region. 

Huge thanks to Substack for hosting this! 

Sponsors

- Today’s episode is brought to you by Scale AI. Scale partners with the U.S. government to fuel America’s AI advantage through their data foundry. The Air Force, Army, Defense Innovation Unit, and Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Office all trust Scale to equip their teams with AI-ready data and the technology to build powerful applications. Scale recently introduced Defense Llama, Scale's latest solution available for military personnel. With Defense Llama, military personnel can harness the power of AI to plan military or intelligence operations and understand adversary vulnerabilities. If you’re interested in learning more on how Scale powers frontier AI capabilities, go to https://scale.com/dwarkesh

To sponsor future episodes, go to: https://www.dwarkeshpatel.com/p/advertise

Sarah's Books
I highly, highly recommend both

"The Wars for Asia, 1911–1949" 
https://www.amazon.com/Wars-Asia-1911-1949-S-Paine/dp/1107697476

and 

"The Japanese Empire: Grand Strategy from the Meiji Restoration to the Pacific War" 
https://www.amazon.com/Japanese-Empire-Strategy-Restoration-Pacific/dp/1107676169

Links
Transcript: https://open.substack.com/pub/dwarkesh/p/sarah-paine-india
Apple Podcasts: http://apple.co/3RFuS7b 
Spotify: https://open.spotify.com/episode/6beCTbPFOXKXNYPAsU7vQa

Timestamps
(0:00:00) - Lecture intro
(0:02:43) - Mao at war, 1949-51
(0:06:12) - Pactomania and Sino-Soviet conflicts
(0:15:14) - The Sino-Indian War
(0:20:32) - Soviet peace in India-Pakistan 
(0:22:32) - US Aid and Alliances
(0:26:46) - The difference with WWII
(0:30:41) - The geopolitical map in 1904 
(0:35:42) - The US alienates Indira Gandhi
(0:43:30) - Instruments of US power
(0:54:13) - Carrier battle groups
(1:03:13) - Q&A begins
(1:05:03) - The appeal of the USSR
(1:10:08) - The last communist premier
(1:16:14) - India and China’s lost opportunity
(1:32:51) - Soviet proxies in foreign politics
(1:58:36) - Bismark’s cunning
(2:03:37) - Training US officers
(2:07:35) - Cruelty in Russian history

metadata.shortSummary: In this episode, Professor Sarah Paine discusses key decisions by leaders like Khrushchev, Mao, and Nehru that shaped South Asia, focusing on the geopolitical dynamics between China, India, the US, and the USSR.
